Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in considering post-review period factors and future plans in assessing residency
Application_Facts: Applicant was short 79 days of the 1095-day physical presence requirement; considered family ties, employment, and absence patterns during and after the review period
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge evaluated residency based on totality of circumstances including post-period conduct
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in considering future plans and post-review factors
Legal_Standard: Residency requirement under section of Citizenship Act; reasonableness standard of review
Assessment_Factor: Family ties, employment, centralization of mode of existence in Canada, travel history
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court from administrative decision
Evidence_Used: Residency logs, employment records, family connections, travel documentation
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section related to 1095-day physical presence requirement
Application_Basis: Physical presence and intention to reside in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Patterns of absence, duration of stays outside Canada, familial and economic ties
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship or remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate centralization of mode of existence in Canada and meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days physically present in Canada (79 days short)
Harm_Assessment: Applicant remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to meet statutory residency requirement for citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Judge considered both quantitative presence and qualitative ties to Canada
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of Citizenship Act regarding physical presence and residency
Evidence_Issues: Reliance on post-review conduct and future intentions in residency assessment
Residency_Compliance: Not met – 79 days short of 1095-day requirement
Evidence_Assessment: Holistic evaluation of applicant’s connection to Canada
Decision_Rationale: The judge properly applied the law by assessing the totality of circumstances; decision was reasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Consideration of future plans and post-period behavior deemed permissible under reasonableness standard
